reviewText: I CAUGHT THE END OF THIS ON TMC AND BEING A PRICE COLLECTOR I HAD TO HAVE IT.IT'S A GREAT MOVIE. A CLASSIC. VICENT PRICE PLAYS THE VILLIAN BUT NOT A HORRORVILLIAN JUST A REGULAR BAD GUY. CHARLES LAUGHTON PUTS ON A GREAT PERFORMANCE ASHIS HANDY MAN BUT REALLY NOT A BAD GUY. THE ENDING IS REALLY GOOD WITH TAYLORAND PRICE. AVA GARDNER IS GORGEOUS. I DON'T HAVE ANY OF HER OTHER MOVIES BUTI WILL LOOK FOR SOME. SHE WAS A GOOD ACTRESS AND PLAYS HER PART WELL. GRREAT MOVIE.

reviewText: Robert Taylor hasn't a chance!!  Even though Ava doesn't realize that she is the Bribe...she achieves that definition by just being AVa and Taylor is a goner...Laughton is characterstically sleazy, Hodiak inoffensive and Vincent Price is his usual evil self.  Well plotted and acted...wish this was in color but is terrific as a noir classic.

reviewText: "The Bribe" is a black and white 1949 melodrama from MGM. It belongs to that rare film sub-genre in the late 40s and early 50s that dealt with political issues - e.g., "Cornered" (1945) had Dick Powell exposing Nazi collaborators, "Flamingo Road" (1949), "All the King's Men" (1949),  and "The Phenix City Story" (1955) dealt with local corruption.Good looking Robert Taylor (1911-69) stars as a government agent on the lookout for engine smugglers who failed to pay their taxes. Taylor achieved some success in filmslike "Magnificent Obsession" (1935), "Camille" (1936), and "A Yank at Oxford" (1938), and this film came at the peak of his career. He followed this one with two of his most memorable - "Ivanhoe" (1952), and "Knights of the Round Table" (1953).Beautiful Ava Gardner (1922-90) appears as a kind of femme fatale. She had done more than a dozen films prior to this, but it was her role as Kitty in "The Killers" (1946) that propelled her to fame and to better roles - "Mogambo" (1953), "The Barefoot Contessa" (1954), "On the Beach" (1959), and Night of the Iguana" (1964).FWIW - this was the first of 3 films teaming Taylor and Gardner, who, according to Gardner, began a love affair during the filming.John Hodiak (1914-55) plays Gardner's drunken husband.  His brief career included memorable roles in "Lifeboat" (1944), "A Bell for Adano" (1945), and "Command Decision" (1948).We tend to think of Vincent Price (1911-93) for all the B horror movies he made in the 50s and 60s, especially the first 3D film "House of Wax" (1953) and the marvelous "The Fly" (1958). But Price was extremely versatile, and did comedies (e.g., "Abbott and Costello Meet Frankenstein" in 1948, Egghead on the TV series "Batman"), period pieces (e.g., "The Ten Commandments" in 1956), and film noir ("Laura" in 1944, "The Long Night" in 1947, "His Kind of Woman" in 1951). Here he is at his sleaziest best.But the real treat in this film is Charles Laughton (1899-1962),  arguably the most capable actor in Hollywood's golden era. His performances in films such as "Mutiny on the Bounty" (1936) and "Witness for the Prosecution " (1958) are peerless, and when you consider he received best actor nominations for both films, separated by more than 20 years, this by itself speaks volumes. He won the best actor award for his portrayal in another British bio pic "The Private Life of Henry VIII" (1933) and gave unforgettable performances as Quasimodo in "The Hunchback of Norte Dame" (1939), Inspector Javert in "Les Miserables" (1935).Look for Samuel Hinds (1875-1948) in a brief role as a doctor. Hinds was the fireworks- making father in "You Can't Take It With You" (1938). Despite beginning his film career at the age of 54, Hinds made 200+ films and is best known as Dr. Stephen Kildare from the film series.Robert Z Leonard (1889-1968) directs. He was nominated for an Oscar for "The Divorcee" (1930) and "The Great Ziegfeld" (1936) and made over 150 films between 1913 and 1957, most of them relatively light fare.The film makes some attempts at film noir, but never really reaches that level, either in exposition or in camera work. The NY Times called it "a folly and nothing more...a piece of pure romantic fiction, as lurid as it is absurd." Leslie Halliwell  called it a "steamy melodrama with pretensions but only moderate entertainment value despite high gloss." Not surprisingly it was a dud at the box office, despite having some bankable talent.Bottom line - it's an OK melodrama and attempt at film noir, with some very engaging performances.Note - the film is better than OK but I didn't like it so much. On a 10 point scale it would get a 7 out of 10, but on a 5 point scale it only gets a 3 out of 5.
summary: "Hitten is a crook and Rigby is a cop"

reviewText: A top cast in an enjoyable tropical noir with all the one liners and cliches.  The romantic angle between Taylor and Gardner limps a little but this is well compensated by Laughton's excellent performance as the fat man 'who sweats a lot'.  Period style of the 40's required the men to wear jackets and ties, and you feel sorry for the poor souls sweating in the humid tropical heat.  Despite a weak story line, it is a gem for noir lovers.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Superb noir of its period.  You've got Robert Taylor on the fade.  Ava Gardner ravishingly on the rise.  Vincent Price at his wicked best  at villainy and Charles Laughton giving his usual acting lesson to all the others.  All this talent in a potboiler just made for a evening of intrigue and romantic daring do.  All the elements are there and the cast lifts this 'B' movie to 'A' status.  It's dark and dirty and has a bang up finale that's been stolen by everybody including Steve Martin (in Dead Men Don't Wear Plaid).  My personal favorite is Laughton who makes every character he embodies completely unique and yet universal but he's closely followed by Price who knew his way around a bad guy and Ava's world weary wanton woman (say that 3 times fast) delivering her jaded lines with a bite that portends great things ahead for her.  The only weak link in the whole darn thing is the titular star Robert Taylor...while he exudes the same sort of world weariness that Ava projects effortlessly...with his performance it comes across with the raw edge of a knife held by the blade rather than the hilt.  He seems vaguely out of place and is what keeps this from taking it's rightful place with the acknowledged great noirs of the period.  But all that aside it's entertaining from beginning to end and filled with fine little moments that illuminate both villainy and heroism in shadows and light.  It's great fun and if you don't take my word for it remember that Steve Martin and Carl Reiner remembered it when they made their own overlooked comedy classic...the aforementioned (ten bucks says the new generation has to google that) Dead Men Don't Wear Plaid.
summary: You Shouldn't Have To Be Bribed To Watch This Classic

reviewText: I have been looking for this one for awhile now, not a bad movie - all great characters with some great actors, interesting enough plot with lots of double crossings, I like the scene where Taylor is pulled into the sea whilst fishing.And of course picking out the shots used in DMDWP was fun.
summary: The Bride ... followed up from "Dead men don't wear plaid"
Title: N/A

reviewText: For the longest time there was a staff review on here that absolutely panned this movie.  There were no other reviews.  That review sort soured me on buying this 2nd hand.  I very much wanted to see this because "Dead Men Don't Wear Plaid" borrowed heavily from "The Bribe".  Martin's character Rigby Reardon is named from this movie.  Matlin's Classic Movie Guide also panned this movie.  Maybe some people just don't get it, had a bad meal or fought with their spouse before they watched the movie.  In Maltin's guide the reviewer states something like Taylor is sleep-walking through his role or looks embarassed.  I don't see anything like that.  How could he be sleepy he's working next a slutry and radiant Gardner.  She is just a beauty in this movie.  And then there's Laughton-what a performance.  Every scene he is in is riveting.  Last is Price in a brilliant role.  How can someone not like this movie.  I'll admit the engine graft plot device is prosaic and I'll agree with Ursini's theory, ie nobody watches these movies for plot, for this movie.
Title: N/A
